Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Grant to Develop An Online Immersive Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Shaw University's Targeted Infusion project entitled: Develop a 3D Immersive Online Environment, has the goal to increase the number of STEM majors by targeting entering freshman taking the University required Freshman Studies course, and to retain existing STEM students through the establishment of academic and social support networks. The project will infuse the Freshman Studies courses with a new technology- the creation of a 3D online virtual world in which students will be exposed to topics in science and technology as well as careers in STEM. This project will be an avenue in which all students entering Shaw University will be exposed to STEM disciplines. The anticipated outcomes from this project include the development of a technology rich curriculum, an increase in the number of students choosing a STEM discipline, an increase in the retention rate of STEM students, students that are better prepared to enter graduate and professional school, and students who are more informed about careers in STEM.
An online format such as a "virtual world" allows students to visit places they may not have the opportunity to do so otherwise. They will be able to experience and see what scientists in various fields do without leaving their homes or classroom. In a virtual world, through their Avatars, students are not merely observers but participants. They will be able to walk into a lab and conduct experiments. The use of a gaming format provides a means to make learning fun and engaging. During the Freshman Studies course, all students will work in teams, fostering cooperative learning. STEM students will then be organized into cohorts during the freshman year providing students with social and academic networks, crucial in the adjustment to college from high school. This project will provide a blueprint for the implementation of a cost-effective and technology rich environment that can be used to recruit and retain STEM majors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to: (1) retain existing majors using "gaming" and (2) recruit students into non-traditional STEM disciplines. We proposed to use "gaming" as a means to expose and engage students to one field of STEM, forensic science.  A key component of this project was the development of an online STEM game entitle, CSI Adventure. The game was developed using the Unity game engine, and all code is written in Unity JavaScript.

CSI Adventure is a forensic logic game designed to stimulate new Shaw University students' interest in STEM and to engage and expose returning students to a specific field of STEM, forensic science. The game puts the player into the fole of a forensic investigator who must solve a series of unique, fictional murder cases in various locations. The principle of the game is to combine logic and fun with scientific techniques to encourage students' interest in pursuing a career in STEM. By allowing the player to perform a variety of scientific tests on evidence found in the game, and using his/her own logic to solve the cases based on the results of those tests, we wanted to expose students to the application of scientific methodology and critical thinking in a real world STEM career.

Student interest and feedback concerning the use of gaming was assessed through surveys.  The game was initially sampled by 34 students in two freshmen level biology courses (BIO 111 and BIO 211). Students played the CSI for the majority of a class period (40 minutes) and then completed a survey that asked for demographic data, their impression of the game, and its effect on their scientific knowledge and interest. Subsequently, 144 students from two freshmen level biology classes (BIO 111 and BIO 211) as well as several biology upperclassmen played the game. On a Likert scale from 1-5, 5 being the highest, students found the game to be easy to learn (3.931 out of 5), fun (also 3.931 out of 5), claimed it improved their knowledge of science (3.655 out of 5) and that it made them more intested in science (3.759 out of 5).

To recruit  students into non-traditional STEM disciplines we exposed students to a variety of different STEM disciplines/careers. Traditionally, approximately 85% of incoming STEM majors at Shaw University desire to pursue a career in medicine. Unfortunately many of these students find the academic rigors of the pre-med curriculum too daunting but are not aware of other STEM career options.  During this project we were able to expose over 50 students to other STEM disciplines/careers such as ecology, forestry, and wildlife conservation through field trips and camping in locations such as Belle W. Baruch Institute of Coastal Ecology and Forest Science of Clemson University on Pawley's Island, SC; the Red Wolf Recovery Center in Pettigrew State Park;  and marshlands in eastern North Carolina. Students met with scientists, educational staff from the NC Museum of Natural Sciences (who led one trip), along with park rangers, who talked with the students about the academic routes they had taken to get to their current positions. Success of this type of exposure to nontraditional STEM careers was evidenced by the students' creation of an Ecology club in 2014.

The Intellectual Merit of this project lies with the application of "gaming" as an innovative teaching pedagogy and the exposure of students to nontraditional disciplines in science. The use of a "gaming" format provided a means not only to make learning fun and engaging but allowed students to apply inquiry based learning and critical thinking to solve cases in this game.  In this project, we were able to both create our own game and to utilize it in several biology courses.
